Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
Comments_List: Analytical writing skills
horrible class

I learned how to go to Beinecke and do archival research. I learned a lot about the Harlem Renaissance. Dr. Reed uses a lot of interesting sources in his lectures such as songs and pieces of art that are not as prevalent in the Harlem Renaissance cannon.
I learned a lot about reading and interpreting poetry. I also developed analytical writing skills and made use of the Beinecke resources for the first time.
I learned about a broad range of texts produced within the Harlem renaissance
Good overview of Harlem Renaissance authors and artists
I don't think that the course was very well taught.
Learned about the literature and art of the Harlem Renaissance
I learned about key figures in the Harlem Renaissance. I also understood key debates surrounding race, art, and power, and how these were developed during that time period.

This course is a great, representative survey of the Harlem Renaissance - it covers all the niches. Professor Reed's lectures always added to the discussions that would otherwise have surrounded the readings. He usually brings in extra materials to give you an expanded sense of the cultural and political context of the works that we read, which I think is very helpful. He's also very straightforward and helpful in his essay assignments, and will help you get better at these kinds of argumentative essays, if that's something you feel less confident about.
How to analytically read historical texts, and provide insight. Also, how to look at texts in the context of the time they were written in.
I learned what the Harlem Renaissance was for the first time. I also learned how to engage with the texts of the era which was very interesting.
I learned a lot about various writers and their works during the Harlem Renaissance.
I learned a lot about Harlem Renaissance culture in the 1920s!
A lot about the various components of the Harlem Renaissance: literary, cultural, historical.
I learned a little about the Harlem Renaissance

The Harlem Renaissance course provided an extensive survey of literature and poetry that allowed students to be immersed in the ideas and arguments formulated within the Black-led social, cultural, and political movements of the early 20th century. I really enjoyed our ability to read so much primary source material through books, as well as the opportunity to go in the Beinecke Archives.
A good survey of important literatureboth poetry and proseof the Harlem Renaissance.
Great books to read

I learned very little in this class, but did get to read some great poems and books by some great authors. However, you could probably get an A in this class without ever reading a full book and just skimming the pages, which discourages people to really engage with the material.
Developed rhetorical and analytical writing skills. Looked at all different kinds of texts, and made connections between many of these texts
Nothing.
I developed the ability to think about the historical implications on black culture by major movements such as the Harlem Renaissance.
Material/assigned readings were really interesting, but lectures were a snooze

An understanding of the important literary and artistic figures of the Harlem Renaissance (in other words, the "intellectual circle" of the period). Also an understanding of major debates of contemporary black art: is there an intrinsic blackness? must a black artist project her "blackness" through her art? and etc. Also engaged with discussions of "passing" and "the folk."

Strengths: Amazing teaching fellows. The reading assignments were really interesting. Additionally I liked the essays we had to write.

Weaknesses: Lecture was a bit dry. I found it hard to pay attention to what Dr. Reed was saying even though he said very interesting things. He was just not very exciting.

Strengths:
-Professor Reed is really passionate and funny
-The readings and course material is very interesting and takes from a wide range of unique authors
-The essay assignments are very thought provoking

Weaknesses:
-Classes and sections are better when attendance is high. I noticed many lectures were missing quite a few students
-Sometimes the readings for the week were heavy and it was hard to get them done (especially with poetry books, since they take a long time to interpret)
Not well structured

Strength: Having a section for this class was helpful, as it allowed us to discuss the txts.
Weakness: I thought that it was quite hard to follow Professor Reed in lecture sometimes. I think his lecturers could have been more engaging.
Reed is a pretty dry lecturer
My section was great, but the lectures were not informative.

Strengths: Interesting readings (well curated), important course for understanding black american history (through the lens of literature + art)

Weakness: Sadly, students were not very engaged in the course. While Reed is clearly brilliant and delivers wonderful commentary, the delivery wasn't always the most successful. 

Improvement: I appreciate the focus on the literature/art, but I think it would have been more effective to start each class with a little more history to contextual the era, movement, and literature of focus for the day.
A strength could be the lectures - they weren't very engaging and considering how I did in the class they weren't essential to get a good grade.
I think lectures could be a little bit more interesting, and interactive so as to keep students engaged.

lecture was not engaging and very difficult to follow. Slides were not informative so there was no clear direction to the lecture. I never quite understood the context of what he was talking about. 
Section was great and I learned a lot there.
The syllabus of the course is great.
Discussion section is very strong and an ideal environment to discuss the reading material assigned. Lectures were less helpful in understanding the material and were not very engaging.
Horrible lecture, Prof Reed read off a sheet of paper and lectures were a boring close reading of obscure passages in the works we were reading. MUST GET A GOOD TA OR ELSE THIS CLASS WILL BE HARD

In my opinion, the course should be converted to a seminar format. The lecture was poorly attended because the majority of students in the class were only there for an easy credit. In a seminar format, only students who genuinely want to be there would be there.
The weakness of the course is that lecture was seemingly useless. The things we learned did not help whatsoever in expanding the learning done in section.
Lot of good, important books were on the reading list. However, lecture was not very engaging

The best strength was Professor Reed's understanding of the material, synthesizing it in lecture, and the creative room he provided in our essay assignments to choose what novels and poems we most wanted to analyze.  The best improvement would be to make lecture attendance and section attendance mandatory.
There needs to be an overarching narrative or flow to the course in order to keep students engaged in a large lecture class. Without it, there is no sense of continuity between lectures.

The best part was getting to do research in the Beinecke--I got to look at the original, handwritten manuscript of Their Eyes Were Watching God (!). I also really enjoyed the 1920s music that Prof. Reed played in class. The biggest weakness was that the vast majority of students skipped lecture.

Strengths: great direction
Weakness: Lectures need to be organized and slides should be public.

The class has really great material as assigned reading, however the lectures were not worth going to. The lectures were not necessarily informative and werent engaging. The professor just read off of his page and went into deep literary analysis of a paragraph or two from the peice or book assigned for that days reading. I wouldve liked to have seen some history context, background etc. on the book or author to give us a better understanding of why/how the piece was relevant, influential, etc. instead of just going into P.h.D. level analysis of a single sentence which no one could keep up with. Often it seemed like the lectures were rambling and didnt help me understand any of the works better. The writing credit option was incredibly easy, but the hardest part about it was understanding what the prompt even wanted. The second assignment where we had to go to the Beinecke to look at old works to help us understand a work better was awesome, but he first paper was so difficult to figure out what he expected us to write.
Lectures were sometimes slow, but the subject matter was very interesting. Section was very useful for clarifying points in lecture and looking at topics through a different lens
This course was a disappointment. There was no student engagement because the lectures were non-cohesive and there was no effort required by the teacher
TAs are very understanding for students. Lectures must be improved. Long blocks of quotes and extended media during lecture do little to supplement student learning.
More clear assignment instructions and a rubric would have been useful.

This course covered really interesting material and topics but was not condensed in a way that was coherent. It seemed like there was no common theme throughout. In the lecture there was not room to get in depth with the material. I think this would have made a better seminar.

Strength: cool materials, easy workload, chill TAs
Weaknesses: Lectures had little structure and by the end of the semester weren't worth going to, material has so much potential that its kind of sad this was just reduced to a gut

The lectures were OUTSTANDING. I learned much about "the folk," publishing and patronage, literary magazines circulating at the time, visual art and music of the period. Professor Reed incorporated into his lectures a wealth of primary sources (for example, the music of Bessie Smith) to draw connections between the literary works and other contemporaneous art forms. Lectures, unfortunately, were poorly attended; and, while this didn't in any way detract from Professor Reed's delivery of material, it did make for a rather sparse learning environment. Perhaps slightly more interaction between lecturer and students could be added in--a few Q and As interspersed throughout the lectures. The essay assignments were engaging, and I especially enjoyed the second assignment, in which we were prompted to conduct primary source research in the Beinecke's prominent Harlem Renaissance collection.
Incredibly material and section, not a great lecture.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It wasn't challenging, and I learned a lot about the subject matter. This course is an ideal course to take because of those reasons. Additionally, showing up to lecture does not determine your grade, so just put a lot of effort into section to ensure a high grade.

Yes, for those interested in developing their writing skills in a non-seminar setting. I also recommend it to people interested in the works of James Weldon Johnson, Zora Neale Hurston and other writers of the Harlem Renaissance, since their understanding of them developed greatly over the course of the semester.
It is a good writing credit. You only have to write 3 papers and can tailor it to a text you are interested in. I did not find lecture to be very engaging though.
Yes, good overview lecture course with very little work.
I would recommend it to be taken if it were offered as a seminar - Prof Reed was really knowledgeable, but the lecture style was not conducive to most students' learning.
You get what you put in.
Interesting easy class. Important literature for people to read!
Yes, assuming nothing in the course changes it's an easy A.
Yes, the course material is very interesting and important.

Yes! Professor Reed is a fantastic lecturer if you are willing to put away the distractions and listen. He's not as flashy as some professors, but he is really great at actually making an interesting argument in his lectures - while also teaching you how to read the texts within new historical and ideological contexts. He always brings in magazine covers, other visual art, or music to supplement his discussion of the literature.
Yes, it's a good writing credit for those who might struggle in other writing classes, and the content and topic of the papers is interesting.
This class is worthwhile if you have a good TA. I would not have felt engaged with the course at all without section and being able to discuss the readings with my peers.
I would recommend this course because the reading is very interesting and students will get a very good introduction to a lot of Harlem Renaissance works.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student.  For me personally, the discussion section made the course, as the conversations and was engaging and intellectually stimulating.
No please dont take this course if its a lecture!
Yes for sure take this course!
Do not take this course unless you can be sure your TA will be a fair grader.
No

Yes, I am very grateful to have had the opportunity to read this important literature, poetry, as well as the visual and auditory art from the Harlem Renaissance, and study it through a critical academic lens.

Not in its current form. They had trouble finding TFs, and quite a few of them were, to say the least, unmotivated and unprepared to teach. The lectures were rather dry, but that wasn't the course's weakest aspect.

Unless its taught as a seminar, dont take it unless you want an easy writing credit and a lottery of what TA youre going to have  could be a great AfAm/English TA or a random TA they hired to fill spots. If you truly want a deep-dive into the history and literature of the Harlem Renaissance, opt for a seminar version of this class because I got nothing out of the lecture-style.
Absolutely, great writing course about a very important time period
No.
Definitely. Get that WR credit.
The content is very interesting. The weekly workload is low. Lectures can be hard to follow and the non-WR section is not particularly informative.
I would recommend it if they are interested in this type of literature.

Gut. Books are actually interesting and worth reading on your own, but the course load for this (especially for the non-writing sections) was light as hell and you could manage without attending lectures

I would recommend, but with caveats. Lectures are outstanding; sections are far less so. My TA was a graduate student in the global health program, and was not at all equipped to TA the course. I got a lot out of the lectures and my independent readings of the works. But the second element of the course--small discussions lead by a knowledgeable graduate student--was entirely lacking. Take the course for Professor Reed's lectures and the great works of literature; try to get a qualified TA.
Everyone should take this class. It should be required for everybody. Take it!!
